node.title: "AGT" contestant Jane "Nightbirde" Marczewski dies at 31
node.description: She was suffering from cancer. She'd stunned the "America's Got Talent" judges with her performance of an original song called "It's OK."

node.title: Heartland Group posts $47m half-year profit
node.description: Financial services company Heartland Group's bottom line has grown on the back of increased lending and higher margins.

node.title: Incoming travellers to get pack with 3 rapid antigen tests - Ardern
node.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern says travellers coming into Auckland Airport will be issued with a pack including three rapid antigen tests, information and advice.

node.title: 'A mockery of the justice system': Rapist plays rugby in Fiji while serving sentence
node.description: Fiji's Ministry for Women and a human rights advocate have condemned Amenoni Nasilasila participation in the Wardens rugby sevens side.

node.title: Final "Arthur" episode airs after 25 seasons
node.description: The show was first broadcast in 1996, and fans of all ages tuned in to the last episode and shared their thoughts on social media.

node.title: Covid-19: cases growing in Whanganui
node.description: Covid-19 is continuing its spread into central and western parts of the North Island, with active cases now confirmed in RangitÄ«kei, Whanganui and the Ruapehu district.

node.title: Heaphy Bridge on Great Walk irreparable
node.description: The flood-damaged Heaphy Bridge on the Heaphy Track has been written off by structural engineers and cannot be fixed.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 2846 community cases, 143 in hospital
node.description: There are 2846 Covid-19 cases in the community today and 143 people in hospital with the virus, the Ministry of Health reports.

node.title: Field hospital plan for Northland unlikely to come to fruition, DHB says
node.description: The Northland DHB says a field hospital in its pandemic plan is "extremely unlikely" to be used.

node.title: NZ Paralympians 'ready to get into it'
node.description: The New Zealand Paralympic team heads to Beijing this week, excited about competition after watching the Olympic Games.

node.title: Political leaders should 'get off their high horses' - Jim Bolger
node.description: Former prime minister Jim Bolger says political leaders should "get off their high horses" and meet with those occupying Parliament's lawn.

node.title: Emergency ambulance won't enter protest zone after hostility
node.description: Wellington's only emergency ambulance service will no longer attend emergencies within the protest area at Parliament.

node.title: Govt make $200k funding available as ex-Cyclone Dovi re-classified
node.description: The government has classified ex-cyclone Dovi as a medium-scale adverse event, making $200,000 of funding available to help recovering efforts.

node.title: Russia's latest Ukraine moves violate international law - Foreign Affairs minister
node.description: Russia's recognition of Ukraine rebel regions as independent may be a calculated act by the president to create a pretext for invasion, Nanaia Mahuta says.

node.title: Homicide investigation launched after death of man in Nelson
node.description: A man has died after being shot at a house in central Nelson this afternoon.

node.title: Beijing adds fertility services to insurance coverage
node.description: Beijing will include more than a dozen fertility services in a government-backed medical insurance scheme as official data shows China's birth rate dropped to a record low in 2021.

node.title: Long Covid: Concern over support as Air NZ refuses cover to ex-employee
node.description: The government is being urged to remove any impediments facing Long Covid sufferers seeking financial support after Air New Zealand declined injury cover to a sufferer it made redundant.

node.title: Parliament protest: Multicultural NZ calls for govt to engage with leaders
node.description: Multicultural New Zealand is calling on the government to show compassion towards the protesters occupying Parliament grounds.

node.title: Person seriously injured, Armed Offenders Squad at Nelson property
node.description: A person is understood to have been seriously injured at a house in central Nelson.

node.title: Biden interviews with Supreme Court candidates have begun
node.description: The president previously said he has narrowed his list down to four choices. He is expected to announce a nominee by the end of February.

node.title: Boil water notice for parts of the West Coast
node.description: The Buller District Council says Westport and Carters Beach residents should boil all water before drinking and using it for food preparation, until further notice.

node.title: Juwan Howard suspended for rest of regular season after hitting Wisconsin assistant
node.description: Three players were also suspended and Wisconsin's head coach was fined for violating the Big Ten's sportsmanship policies.

node.title: Utah father arrested after allegedly telling 4-year-old to shoot at police
node.description: Police said an officer was able to swipe the gun away as a round was fired, and the officer only sustained a "minor wound" to his arm.

node.title: $140m new funding for MÄori and Pacific Omicron response
node.description: Associate Minister of Health Peeni Henare says the government knows Omicron is likely to disproportionately affect MÄori and Pasifika communities, so they're making sure they getting the support andâ¦

node.title: Former teacher's lifelong collection of African American history to go up for auction
node.description: The collection features more than 20,000 items, including memorabilia from civil rights icons and superstars of the sports world.

node.title: Putin orders Russian forces into Ukraine's breakaway regions
node.description: The U.S. warned last week that recognizing the self-declared "People's Republics" of Donetsk and Luhansk would violate international law and would "necessitate a swift and firm response" from America and its allies.

node.title: Protest backer hopes it may help revival of $18 billion tourism industry
node.description: One of the people funding the Parliament protest says it makes no sense to maintain a quarantine system at the border now that Covid-19 cases are rife in the community. Audio

node.title: Many restaurants face "extinction" amid COVID, inflation and staffing shortages
node.description: As many as 80% of restaurants nationwide say they are in danger of closing without assistance.

node.title: Jury begins deliberations in Ahmaud Arbery hate crimes trial
node.description: Greg and Travis McMichael and William "Roddie" Bryan have already been convicted in state court and sentenced to life in prison.

node.title: Covid-19 leaves schools short of teachers
node.description: Cases of Covid-19 among children and teachers are forcing schools to roster entire year groups home or offer online learning for those who want it.
